1.2: until the day he was taken to heaven. Before he was taken to heaven, he gave instructions through the Holy Spirit to the apostles, whom he had chosen.

1.5: John baptized with water, but in a few days you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.”

1.7: Yeshua told them, “You don’t need to know about times or periods that the Father has determined by his own authority.
1.8: But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes to you. Then you will be my witnesses to testify about me in Jerusalem, throughout Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”
1.9: After he had said this, he was taken to heaven. A cloud hid him so that they could no longer see him.
1.10: They were staring into the sky as he departed. Suddenly, two men in white clothes stood near them.
1.11: They asked, “Why are you men from Galilee standing here looking at the sky? Yeshua, who was taken from you to heaven, will come back in the same way that you saw him go to heaven.”
1.12: Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mountain called the Mount of Olives. It is near Jerusalem, about half a mile away.
1.13: When they came into the city, Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon the Zealot, and Judas (son of James) went to the second-story room where they were staying.
1.14: The apostles had a single purpose as they devoted themselves to prayer. They were joined by some women, including Mary (the mother of Yeshua), and they were joined by his brothers.
1.15:
At a time when about 120 disciples had gathered together, Peter got up and spoke to them.
He said,
1.16: “Brothers, what the Holy Spirit predicted through David in Scripture about Judas had to come true. Judas led the men to arrest Yeshua.
1.17: He had been one of us and had been given an active role in this ministry.
1.18: With the money he received from the wrong he had done, he bought a piece of land where he fell headfirst to his death. His body split open, and all his internal organs came out.
1.19: Everyone living in Jerusalem knows about this. They even call that piece of land Akeldama, which means ‘Field of Blood’ in their dialect.
1.20:
You’ve read in Psalms, ‘Let his home be deserted, and let no one live there,’ and ‘Let someone else take his position.’”
“Therefore, someone must be added to our number to serve with us as a witness that Yeshua came back to life.

1.22: This person must have been with us from the time that John was baptizing people to the day that Yeshua was taken from us.”

1.24: Then they prayed, “Lord, you know everyone’s thoughts. Show us which of these two you have chosen.
1.25: Show us who is to take the place of Judas as an apostle, since Judas abandoned his position to go to the place where he belongs.”
1.26: They drew names to choose an apostle. Matthias was chosen and joined the eleven apostles.

2.2: Suddenly, a sound like a violently blowing wind came from the sky and filled the whole house where they were staying.
2.3: Tongues that looked like fire appeared to them. The tongues arranged themselves so that one came to rest on each believer.
2.4: All the believers were filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages as the Spirit gave them the ability to speak.
2.5: Devout Jewish men from every nation were living in Jerusalem.
2.6: They gathered when they heard the wind. Each person was startled to recognize his own dialect when the disciples spoke.
2.7: Stunned and amazed, the people in the crowd said, “All of these men who are speaking are Galileans.
2.8: Why do we hear them speaking in our native dialects?
2.9: We’re Parthians, Medes, and Elamites. We’re people from Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, the province of Asia,
2.10: Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, and the country near Cyrene in Libya. We’re Jewish people, converts to Judaism, and visitors from Rome,
2.11: Crete, and Arabia. We hear these men in our own languages as they tell about the miracles that God has done.”
2.12: All of these devout men were stunned and puzzled. They asked each other, “What can this mean?”
2.13: Others said jokingly, “They’re drunk on sweet wine.”
2.14: Then Peter stood up with the eleven apostles. In a loud voice he said to them, “Men of Judea and everyone living in Jerusalem! You must understand this, so pay attention to what I say.
2.15: These men are not drunk as you suppose. It’s only nine in the morning.
2.16: Rather, this is what the prophet Joel spoke about:
2.17:
‘In the last days, God says,
    I will pour my Spirit on everyone.

        Your old men will dream dreams.

    I will pour my Spirit on my servants, on both men and women.

I will work miracles in the sky and give signs on the earth:
    blood, fire, and clouds of smoke.
2.20:

    and the moon will become as red as blood
        before the terrifying day of the Lord comes.

2.23: By using men who don’t acknowledge Moses’ Teachings, you crucified Yeshua, who was given over to death by a plan that God had determined in advance.
2.24: But God brought him from death back to life and destroyed the pains of death, because death had no power to hold him.
2.25:
This is what David meant when he said about Yeshua:
‘I always see the Lord in front of me.
    I cannot be moved because he is by my side.
2.26:
That is why my heart is glad and my tongue rejoices.
    My body also rests securely
2.27:
because you do not abandon my soul to the grave
    or allow your holy one to decay.
2.28:
You make the path of life known to me.
    In your presence there is complete joy.’
2.29: “Brothers, I can tell you confidently that our ancestor David died and was buried and that his tomb is here to this day.
2.30: David was a prophet and knew that God had promised with an oath that he would place one of David’s descendants on his throne.
2.31: David knew that the Messiah would come back to life, and he spoke about that before it ever happened. He said that the Messiah wouldn’t be left in the grave and that his body wouldn’t decay.
2.32: “God brought this man Yeshua back to life. We are all witnesses to that.
2.33: God used his power to give Yeshua the highest position. Yeshua has also received and has poured out the Holy Spirit as the Father had promised, and this is what you’re seeing and hearing.
2.34:
David didn’t go up to heaven, but he said,
‘The Lord said to my Lord,
    “Take my highest position of power
2.35: until I put your enemies under your control.” ’

2.37: When the people heard this, they were deeply upset. They asked Peter and the other apostles, “Brothers, what should we do?”
2.38: Peter answered them, “All of you must turn to God and change the way you think and act, and each of you must be baptized in the name of Yeshua Christ so that your sins will be forgiven. Then you will receive the Holy Spirit as a gift.
2.39: This promise belongs to you and to your children and to everyone who is far away. It belongs to everyone who worships the Lord our God.”
2.40: Peter said much more to warn them. He urged, “Save yourselves from this corrupt generation.”
2.41: Those who accepted what Peter said were baptized. That day about 3,000 people were added to the group.
2.42: The disciples were devoted to the teachings of the apostles, to fellowship, to the breaking of bread, and to prayer.

2.45: From time to time, they sold their property and other possessions and distributed the money to anyone who needed it.
2.46: The believers had a single purpose and went to the temple every day. They were joyful and humble as they ate at each other’s homes and shared their food.
2.47: At the same time, they praised God and had the good will of all the people. Every day the Lord saved people, and they were added to the group.

3.1: Peter and John were going to the temple courtyard for the three o’clock prayer.
3.2: At the same time, a man who had been lame from birth was being carried by some men. Every day these men would put the lame man at a gate in the temple courtyard. The gate was called Beautiful Gate. There he would beg for handouts from people going into the courtyard.
3.3: When the man saw that Peter and John were about to go into the courtyard, he asked them for a handout.
3.4: Peter and John stared at him. “Look at us!” Peter said.
3.5: So the man watched them closely. He expected to receive something from them.
3.6: However, Peter said to him, “I don’t have any money, but I’ll give you what I do have. Through the power of Yeshua Christ from Nazareth, walk!”
3.7: Peter took hold of the man’s right hand and began to help him up. Immediately, the man’s feet and ankles became strong.
3.8: Springing to his feet, he stood up and started to walk. He went with Peter and John into the temple courtyard. The man was walking, jumping, and praising God.
3.9: All the people saw him walking and praising God.
3.10: They knew that he was the man who used to sit and beg at the temple’s Beautiful Gate. The people were amazed and stunned to see what had happened to him.
3.11: They were excited, and everyone ran to see them at the place called Solomon’s Porch. The man wouldn’t let go of Peter and John.
3.12: When Peter saw this, he said to the people, “Men of Israel, why are you amazed about this man? Why are you staring at us as though we have made him walk by our own power or godly life?
3.13: The God of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob has glorified his servant Yeshua. You handed Yeshua over to Pilate. You rejected him in Pilate’s presence, even though Pilate had decided to let him go free.
3.14: You rejected the man who was holy and innocent. You asked to have a murderer given to you,
3.15: and you killed the source of life. But God brought him back to life, and we are witnesses to that.
3.16: We believe in the one named Yeshua. Through his power alone this man, whom you know, was healed, as all of you saw.
3.17: “And now, brothers, I know that like your rulers you didn’t know what you were doing.
3.18: But in this way God made the sufferings of his Messiah come true. God had predicted these sufferings through all the prophets.
3.19: So change the way you think and act, and turn to God to have your sins removed.
3.20: Then times will come when the Lord will refresh you. He will send you Yeshua, whom he has appointed to be the Christ.
3.21: Heaven must receive Yeshua until the time when everything will be restored as God promised through his holy prophets long ago.
3.22: “Moses said, ‘The Lord your God will send you a prophet, an Israelite like me. Listen to everything he tells you.
3.23: Those who won’t listen to that prophet will be excluded from the people.’
3.24: Samuel and all the prophets who followed him spoke about these days.
3.25: You are the descendants of the prophets and the heirs of the promise that God made to our ancestors when he said to Abraham, ‘Through your descendant all people on earth will be blessed.’
3.26: God has brought his servant back to life and has sent him to you first. God did this to bless you by turning every one of you from your evil ways.”

4.1: Some priests, the officer in charge of the temple guards, and some Sadducees approached Peter and John while they were speaking to the people.
4.2: These religious authorities were greatly annoyed. Peter and John were teaching the people and spreading the message that the dead will come back to life through Yeshua.
4.3: So the temple guards arrested them. Since it was already evening, they put Peter and John in jail until the next day.
4.4: But many of those who had heard the message became believers, so the number of men who believed grew to about 5,000.
4.5: The next day the Jewish rulers, the leaders, and the experts in Moses’ Teachings met in Jerusalem.
4.6: The chief priest Annas, Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and the rest of the chief priest’s family were present.
4.7: They made Peter and John stand in front of them and then asked, “By what power or in whose name did you do this?”
4.8: Then Peter, because he was filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, “Rulers and leaders of the people,
4.9: today you are cross-examining us about the good we did for a crippled man. You want to know how he was made well.
4.10: You and all the people of Israel must understand that this man stands in your presence with a healthy body because of the power of Yeshua Christ from Nazareth. You crucified Yeshua Christ, but God has brought him back to life.
4.11: He is the stone that the builders rejected, the stone that has become the cornerstone.
4.12: No one else can save us. Indeed, we can be saved only by the power of the one named Yeshua and not by any other person.”
4.13: After they found out that Peter and John had no education or special training, they were surprised to see how boldly they spoke. They realized that these men had been with Yeshua.
4.14: When they saw the man who was healed standing with Peter and John, they couldn’t say anything against the two apostles.
4.15: So they ordered Peter and John to leave the council room and began to discuss the matter among themselves.
4.16: They said, “What should we do to these men? Clearly, they’ve performed a miracle that everyone in Jerusalem knows about. We can’t deny that.
4.17: So let’s threaten them. Let’s tell them that they must never speak to anyone about the one named Yeshua. Then the news about the miracle that they have performed will not spread any further among the people.”
4.18: They called Peter and John and ordered them never to teach about Yeshua or even mention his name.
4.19: Peter and John answered them, “Decide for yourselves whether God wants people to listen to you rather than to him.
4.20: We cannot stop talking about what we’ve seen and heard.”
4.21: The authorities threatened them even more and then let them go. Since all the people were praising God for what had happened, the authorities couldn’t find any way to punish Peter and John.
4.22: (The man who was healed by this miracle was over 40 years old.)
4.23: When Peter and John were released, they went to the other apostles and told them everything the chief priests and leaders had said.
4.24: When the apostles heard this, they were united and loudly prayed to God, “Master, you made the sky, the land, the sea, and everything in them.
4.25:
You said through the Holy Spirit, who spoke through your servant David (our ancestor),
‘Why do the nations act arrogantly?
    Why do their people devise useless plots?
4.26:
Kings take their stand.
    Rulers make plans together
        against the Lord and against his Messiah.’
4.27: “In this city Herod and Pontius Pilate made plans together with non-Jewish people and the people of Israel. They made their plans against your holy servant Yeshua, whom you anointed.
4.28: Through your will and power, they did everything that you had already decided should be done.
4.29: “Lord, pay attention to their threats now, and allow us to speak your word boldly.
4.30: Show your power by healing, performing miracles, and doing amazing things through the power and the name of your holy servant Yeshua.”
4.31: When the apostles had finished praying, their meeting place shook. All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit and continued to speak the word of God boldly.
4.32: The whole group of believers lived in harmony. No one called any of his possessions his own. Instead, they shared everything.
4.33: With great power the apostles continued to testify that the Lord Yeshua had come back to life. God’s abundant good will was with all of them.
4.34: None of them needed anything. From time to time, people sold land or houses and brought the money
4.35: to the apostles. Then the money was distributed to anyone who needed it.
4.36: Joseph, a descendant of Levi, had been born on the island of Cyprus. The apostles called him Barnabas, which means “a person who encourages.”
4.37: He had some land. He sold it and turned the money over to the apostles.

5.1: A man named Ananias and his wife Sapphira sold some property.
5.2: They agreed to hold back some of the money they had pledged and turned only part of it over to the apostles.
5.3: Peter asked, “Ananias, why did you let Satan fill you with the idea that you could deceive the Holy Spirit? You’ve held back some of the money you received for the land.
5.4: While you had the land, it was your own. After it was sold, you could have done as you pleased with the money. So how could you do a thing like this? You didn’t lie to people but to God!”
5.5: When Ananias heard Peter say this, he dropped dead. Everyone who heard about his death was terrified.
5.6: Some young men got up, wrapped his body in a sheet, carried him outside, and buried him.
5.7: About three hours later Ananias’ wife arrived. She didn’t know what had happened.
5.8:
So Peter asked her, “Tell me, did you sell the land for that price?”
She answered, “Yes, that was the price.”
5.9: Then Peter said to her, “How could you and your husband agree to test the Lord’s Spirit? Those who buried your husband are standing at the door, and they will carry you outside for burial.”
5.10: Immediately, she dropped dead in front of Peter. When the young men came back, they found Sapphira dead. So they carried her outside and buried her next to her husband.
5.11: The whole church and everyone else who heard about what had happened were terrified.
5.12: The people saw the apostles perform many miracles and do amazing things. The believers had a common faith in Yeshua as they met on Solomon’s Porch.
5.13: None of the other people dared to join them, although everyone spoke highly of them.
5.14: More men and women than ever began to believe in the Lord.
5.15: As a result, people carried their sick into the streets. They placed them on stretchers and cots so that at least Peter’s shadow might fall on some sick people as he went by.
5.16: Crowds from the cities around Jerusalem would gather. They would bring their sick and those who were troubled by evil spirits, and each person was cured.
5.17: The chief priest and the whole party of the Sadducees who were with him were extremely jealous. So they took action
5.18: by arresting the apostles and putting them in the city jail.
5.19: But at night an angel from the Lord opened the doors to their cell and led them out of the prison.
5.20: The angel told them, “Stand in the temple courtyard, and tell the people everything about life in Christ.”
5.21:
Early in the morning, after they had listened to the angel, the apostles went into the temple courtyard and began to teach.
The chief priest and those who were with him called together the Jewish council, that is, all the leaders of Israel. They also sent men to the prison to get the apostles.
5.22: When the temple guards arrived at the prison, they didn’t find the apostles. The guards came back and reported,
5.23: “We found the prison securely locked and the guards standing at the doors. However, when we opened the doors, we found no one inside.”
5.24: When the officer of the temple guards and the chief priests heard this, they were puzzled about what could have happened.
5.25: Then someone told them, “The men you put in prison are standing in the temple courtyard. They’re teaching the people.”
5.26: Then the officer of the temple guards went with some of his men to bring back the apostles without using force. After all, the officer and his guards were afraid that the people would stone them to death for using force.
5.27: When they brought back the apostles, they made them stand in front of the council. The chief priest questioned them.
5.28: He said, “We gave you strict orders not to mention Yeshua’s name when you teach. Yet, you’ve filled Jerusalem with your teachings. You want to take revenge on us for putting that man to death.”
5.29: Peter and the other apostles answered, “We must obey God rather than people.
5.30: You murdered Yeshua by hanging him on a cross. But the God of our ancestors brought him back to life.
5.31: God used his power to give Yeshua the highest position as leader and savior. He did this to lead the people of Israel to him, to change the way they think and act, and to forgive their sins.
5.32: We are witnesses to these things, and so is the Holy Spirit, whom God has given to those who obey him.”
5.33: When the men on the council heard this, they became furious and wanted to execute the apostles.
5.34: But a Pharisee named Gamaliel stood up. He was a highly respected expert in Moses’ Teachings. He ordered that the apostles should be taken outside for a little while.
5.35: Then he said to the council, “Men of Israel, consider carefully what you do with these men.
5.36: Some time ago Theudas appeared. He claimed that he was important, and about four hundred men joined him. He was killed, and all his followers were scattered. The whole movement was a failure.
5.37: “After that man, at the time of the census, Judas from Galilee appeared and led people in a revolt. He, too, died, and all his followers were scattered.
5.38: “We should keep away from these men for now. We should leave them alone. I can guarantee that if the plan they put into action is of human origin, it will fail.
5.39: However, if it’s from God, you won’t be able to stop them. You may even discover that you’re fighting against God.”
5.40: The council took his advice. They called the apostles, beat them, ordered them not to speak about the one named Yeshua, and let them go.
5.41: The apostles left the council room. They were happy to have been considered worthy to suffer dishonor for speaking about Yeshua.
5.42: Every day in the temple courtyard and from house to house, they refused to stop teaching and telling the Good News that Yeshua is the Messiah.

6.1: At that time, as the number of disciples grew, Greek-speaking Jews complained about the Hebrew-speaking Jews. The Greek-speaking Jews claimed that the widows among them were neglected every day when food and other assistance was distributed.
6.2: The twelve apostles called all the disciples together and told them, “It’s not right for us to give up God’s word in order to distribute food.
6.3: So, brothers and sisters, choose seven men whom the people know are spiritually wise. We will put them in charge of this problem.
6.4: However, we will devote ourselves to praying and to serving in ways that are related to the word.”
6.5: The suggestion pleased the whole group. So they chose Stephen, who was a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, and they chose Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolaus, who had converted to Judaism in the city of Antioch.
6.6: The disciples had these men stand in front of the apostles, who prayed and placed their hands on these seven men.
6.7: The word of God continued to spread, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem grew very large. A large number of priests accepted the faith.
6.8: Stephen was a man filled with God’s favor and power. He did amazing things and performed miracles.
6.9: One day some men from the cities of Cyrene and Alexandria and the provinces of Cilicia and Asia started an argument with Stephen. They belonged to a synagogue called Freedmen’s Synagogue.
6.10: They couldn’t argue with Stephen because he spoke with the wisdom that the Spirit had given him.
6.11:
Then they bribed some men to lie.
These men said, “We heard him slander Moses and God.”
6.12: The liars stirred up trouble among the people, the leaders, and the experts in Moses’ Teachings. So they went to Stephen, took him by force, and brought him in front of the Jewish council.
6.13: Some witnesses stood up and lied about Stephen. They said, “This man never stops saying bad things about the holy place and Moses’ Teachings.
6.14: We heard him say that Yeshua from Nazareth will destroy the temple and change the customs that Moses gave us.”
6.15: Everyone who sat in the council stared at him and saw that his face looked like an angel’s face.

7.1: Then the chief priest asked Stephen, “Is this true?”
7.2: Stephen answered, “Brothers and fathers, listen to me. The God who reveals his glory appeared to our ancestor Abraham in Mesopotamia. This happened before Abraham lived in Haran.
7.3: God told him, ‘Leave your land and your relatives. Go to the land that I will show you.’
7.4: “Then Abraham left the country of Chaldea and lived in the city of Haran. After his father died, God made him move from there to this land where we now live.
7.5: “Yet, God didn’t give Abraham anything in this land to call his own, not even a place to rest his feet. But God promised to give this land to him and to his descendants, even though Abraham didn’t have a child.
7.6: God told Abraham that his descendants would be foreigners living in another country and that the people there would make them slaves and mistreat them for 400 years.
7.7: God also told him, ‘I will punish the people whom they will serve. After that, they will leave that country and worship me here.’
7.8: “God gave Abraham circumcision to confirm his promise. So when Abraham’s son Isaac was born, Abraham circumcised him on the eighth day. Isaac did the same to his son Jacob, and Jacob did the same to his twelve sons (the ancestors of our tribes).
7.9: “Jacob’s sons were jealous of their brother Joseph. They sold him into slavery, and he was taken to Egypt. But God was with Joseph
7.10: and rescued him from all his suffering. When Joseph stood in the presence of Pharaoh (the king of Egypt), God gave Joseph divine favor and wisdom so that he became ruler of Egypt and of Pharaoh’s whole palace.
7.11: Then a famine throughout Egypt and Canaan brought a lot of suffering. Our ancestors couldn’t find any food.
7.12: When Jacob heard that Egypt had food, he sent our ancestors there. That was their first trip.
7.13: On the second trip, Joseph told his brothers who he was, and Pharaoh learned about Joseph’s family.
7.14: Joseph sent for his father Jacob and his relatives, 75 people in all.
7.15: So Jacob went to Egypt, and he and our ancestors died there.
7.16: They were taken to Shechem for burial in the tomb that Abraham purchased in Shechem from Hamor’s sons.
7.17: “When the time that God had promised to Abraham had almost come, the number of our people in Egypt had grown very large.
7.18: Then a different king, who knew nothing about Joseph, began to rule in Egypt.
7.19: This king was shrewd in the way he took advantage of our people. He mistreated our ancestors. He made them abandon their newborn babies outdoors, where they would die.
7.20: “At that time Moses was born, and he was a very beautiful child. His parents took care of him for three months.
7.21: When Moses was abandoned outdoors, Pharaoh’s daughter adopted him and raised him as her son.
7.22: So Moses was educated in all the wisdom of the Egyptians and became a great man in what he said and did.
7.23: When he was 40 years old, he decided to visit his own people, the Israelites.
7.24: When he saw an Israelite man being treated unfairly by an Egyptian, he defended the Israelite. He took revenge by killing the Egyptian.
7.25: Moses thought his own people would understand that God was going to use him to give them freedom. But they didn’t understand.
7.26: The next day Moses saw two Israelites fighting, and he tried to make peace between them. He said to them, ‘Men, you are brothers. Why are you treating each other unfairly?’
7.27: “But one of the men pushed Moses aside. He asked Moses, ‘Who made you our ruler and judge?
7.28: Do you want to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?’
7.29: After he said that, Moses quickly left Egypt and lived in Midian as a foreigner. In Midian he fathered two sons.
7.30: “Forty years later, a Messenger appeared to him in the flames of a burning bush in the desert of Mount Sinai.
7.31: Moses was surprised when he saw this. As he went closer to look at the bush, the voice of the Lord said to him,
7.32: ‘I am the God of your ancestors—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses began to tremble and didn’t dare to look at the bush.
7.33: The Lord told him, ‘Take off your sandals. The place where you’re standing is holy ground.
7.34: I’ve seen how my people are mistreated in Egypt. I’ve heard their groaning and have come to rescue them. So now I’m sending you to Egypt.’
7.35: “This is the Moses whom the Israelites rejected by saying, ‘Who made you our ruler and judge?’ This is the one God sent to free them and to rule them with the help of the Messenger who appeared to him in the bush.
7.36: This is the man who led our ancestors out of Egypt. He is the person who did amazing things and worked miracles in Egypt, at the Red Sea, and in the desert for 40 years.
7.37: This is the same Moses who told the Israelites, ‘God will send you a prophet, an Israelite like me.’
7.38: This is the Moses who was in the assembly in the desert. Our ancestors and the Messenger who spoke to him on Mount Sinai were there with him. Moses received life-giving messages to give to us,
7.39: but our ancestors were not willing to obey him. Instead, they pushed him aside, and in their hearts they turned back to Egypt.
7.40: They told Aaron, ‘We don’t know what has happened to this Moses, who led us out of Egypt. So make gods who will lead us.’

9.1: Saul kept threatening to murder the Lord’s disciples. He went to the chief priest

Saul asked, “Who are you, sir?”
The person replied, “I’m Yeshua, the one you’re persecuting.
9.6: Get up! Go into the city, and you’ll be told what you should do.”

9.24: but Saul was told about their plot. They were watching the city gates day and night in order to murder him.

9.26: After Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples. But everyone was afraid of him. They wouldn’t believe that he was a disciple.
9.27: Then Barnabas took an interest in Saul and brought him to the apostles. Barnabas told the apostles how Saul had seen the Lord on the road and that the Lord had spoken to him. Barnabas also told them how boldly Saul had spoken about the one named Yeshua in the city of Damascus.

10.1: A man named Cornelius lived in the city of Caesarea. He was a Roman army officer in the Italian Regiment.
10.2: He and everyone in his home were devout and respected God. Cornelius gave many gifts to poor Jewish people and always prayed to God.
10.3: One day, about three in the afternoon, he had a vision. He clearly saw an angel from God come to him and say, “Cornelius!”
10.4:
He stared at the angel and was terrified. Cornelius asked the angel, “What do you want, sir?”
The angel answered him, “God is aware of your prayers and your gifts to the poor, and he has remembered you.
10.5: Send messengers now to the city of Joppa, and summon a man whose name is Simon Peter.
10.6: He is a guest of Simon, a leatherworker, whose house is by the sea.”
10.7: After saying this, the angel left. Cornelius called two of his household servants and a devout soldier, one of those who served him regularly.
10.8: Cornelius explained everything to them and sent them to Joppa.
10.9: Around noon the next day, while Cornelius’ men were on their way and coming close to Joppa, Peter went on the roof to pray.
10.10: He became hungry and wanted to eat. While the food was being prepared, he fell into a trance.
10.11: He saw the sky open and something like a large linen sheet being lowered by its four corners to the ground.
10.12: In the sheet were all kinds of four-footed animals, reptiles, and birds.
10.13: A voice told him, “Get up, Peter! Kill these animals, and eat them.”
10.14: Peter answered, “I can’t do that, Lord! I’ve never eaten anything that is impure or unclean.”
10.15: A voice spoke to him a second time, “Don’t say that the things which God has made clean are impure.”
10.16: This happened three times. Then the sheet was quickly taken into the sky.
10.17: While Peter was puzzled by the meaning of the vision, the men sent by Cornelius found Simon’s house and went to the gate.
10.18: They asked if Simon Peter was staying there.
10.19: Peter was still thinking about the vision when the Spirit said to him, “Three men are looking for you.
10.20: Get up, and go downstairs. Don’t hesitate to go with these men. I have sent them.”
10.21: So Peter went to the men. He said, “I’m the man you’re looking for. Why are you here?”

10.23:
Peter asked the men to come into the house and had them stay overnight.
The next day Peter left with them. Some disciples from Joppa went along.
10.24: The following day they arrived in Caesarea. Cornelius was expecting them and had called his relatives and close friends together.
10.25: When Peter was about to enter Cornelius’ house, Cornelius met him, bowed down, and worshiped Peter.
10.26: But Peter made him get up. He told him, “Stand up! I’m only a man.”
10.27: As Peter talked, he entered Cornelius’ house and found that many people had gathered.
10.28: He said to them, “You understand how wrong it is for a Jewish man to associate or visit with anyone of another race. But God has shown me that I should no longer call anyone impure or unclean.
10.29: That is why I didn’t object to coming here when you sent for me. I want to know why you sent for me.”
10.30: Cornelius answered, “Four days ago I was praying at home. It was at this same time, three o’clock in the afternoon. Suddenly, a man dressed in radiant clothes stood in front of me.
10.31: He said to me, ‘Cornelius, God has heard your prayer and has remembered your gifts to the poor.
10.32: So send messengers to Joppa, and summon a man whose name is Simon Peter. He’s a guest in the home of Simon, a leatherworker who lives by the sea.’
10.33: So I sent for you immediately. Thank you for coming. All of us are here now in the presence of God to listen to everything the Lord has ordered you to say.”
10.34: Then Peter said, “Now I understand that God doesn’t play favorites.
10.35: Rather, whoever respects God and does what is right is acceptable to him in any nation.
10.36: God sent his word to the people of Israel and brought them the Good News of peace through Yeshua Christ. This Yeshua Christ is everyone’s Lord.

They heard these non-Jewish people speaking in other languages and praising God.
Then Peter said,
10.47: “No one can refuse to baptize these people with water. They have received the Holy Spirit in the same way that we did.”

So Peter ordered that they should be baptized in the name of Yeshua Christ.
Then they asked Peter to stay with them for several days.

11.7: I also heard a voice telling me, ‘Get up, Peter! Kill these animals, and eat them.’

12.3: When he saw how this pleased the Jews, he arrested Peter too. This happened during the days of Unleavened Bread.

12.5: So Peter was kept in prison, but the church was praying very hard to God for him.

12.7: Suddenly, an angel from the Lord stood near Peter, and his cell was filled with light. The angel nudged Peter’s side, woke him up, and said, “Hurry! Get up!” At that moment the chains fell from Peter’s hands.
12.8: The angel told him, “Put your shoes on, and get ready to go!” Peter did this. Then the angel told him, “Put your coat on, and follow me.”
12.9: Peter followed the angel out of the cell. He didn’t realize that what the angel was doing was actually happening. He thought he was seeing a vision.

12.12: When Peter realized what had happened, he went to the home of Mary, the mother of John Mark. Many people had gathered at her home and were praying.
12.13: Peter knocked on the door of the entryway, and a servant named Rhoda came to answer.
12.14: When she recognized Peter’s voice, she was so happy that instead of opening the door, she ran back inside and reported, “Peter is standing at the door!”
12.15: The people told her, “You’re crazy!” But she insisted that Peter was at the door. They said, “It has to be his angel.”
12.16: But Peter kept knocking. When they opened the door, they were shocked to see him.
12.17: Peter motioned with his hand to quiet them down and told them how the Lord had taken him out of prison. He added, “Tell James and the other believers about this.” Then he left and went somewhere else.
12.18: In the morning the soldiers were in an uproar over what had happened to Peter.
12.19:
Herod searched for Peter but couldn’t find him. So he questioned the guards and gave orders to have them executed.
Then Herod left Judea and went to Caesarea, where he stayed for a while.
12.20: Herod was very angry with the people of Tyre and Sidon. They were going to meet with Herod. 12.22: The people started shouting, “The voice of a god and not of a man!”
12.23: Immediately, an angel from the Lord killed Herod for not giving glory to God. Herod was eaten by maggots, and he died.
12.24: But God’s word continued to spread and win many followers.
12.25: After Barnabas and Saul delivered the contribution to the leaders in Jerusalem, they returned to Antioch from Jerusalem. They brought John Mark with them.

13.1: Barnabas, Simeon (called the Black), Lucius (from Cyrene), Manaen (a close friend of Herod since childhood), and Saul were prophets and teachers in the church in Antioch.
13.2: While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Set Barnabas and Saul apart for me. I want them to do the work for which I called them.”
13.3: After fasting and praying, Simeon, Lucius, and Manaen placed their hands on Barnabas and Saul, and released them from their work in Antioch.
13.4: After Barnabas and Saul were sent by the Holy Spirit, they went to the city of Seleucia and from there sailed to the island of Cyprus.
13.5: Arriving in the city of Salamis, they began to spread God’s word in the synagogues. John Mark had gone along to help them.
13.6:
They went through the whole island as far as the city of Paphos.
In Paphos they met a Jewish man named Barjesus. He was an astrologer who claimed to be a prophet.
13.7: He was associated with an intelligent man, Sergius Paulus, who was the governor of the island. The governor sent for Barnabas and Saul because he wanted to hear the word of God.
13.8: Elymas, whose name means astrologer, opposed them and tried to distort the meaning of the faith so that the governor wouldn’t believe.
13.9: But Saul, also known as Paul, was filled with the Holy Spirit. He stared at Elymas
13.10: and said, “You are full of dirty tricks and schemes, you son of the devil! You hate everything that has God’s approval. Quit trying to distort the truth about the way the Lord wants people to live.
13.11:
The Lord is against you now. For a while you will be blind, unable to see the light of day.”
Suddenly, Elymas couldn’t see a thing. He tried to find people to lead him.
13.12: When the governor saw what had happened, he believed. The Lord’s teachings amazed him.
13.13: Paul and his men took a ship from Paphos and arrived in Perga, a city in Pamphylia. John Mark deserted them there and went back to Jerusalem.
13.14: Paul and Barnabas left Perga and arrived in Antioch, a city near Pisidia. On the day of worship they went into the synagogue and sat down.
13.15: After reading from Moses’ Teachings and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent a message to Paul and Barnabas. The message said, “Brothers, if you have any words of encouragement for the people, feel free to speak.”
13.16: Then Paul stood up, motioned with his hand, and said, “Men of Israel and converts to Judaism, listen to me.
13.17: The God of the people of Israel chose our ancestors and made them a strong nation while they lived as foreigners in Egypt. He used his powerful arm to bring them out of Egypt,
13.18: and he put up with them for about forty years in the desert.
13.19: Then he destroyed seven nations in Canaan and gave their land to his people as an inheritance.
13.20:
He did all this in about four hundred and fifty years.
“After that he gave his people judges until the time of the prophet Samuel.
13.21: “Then the people demanded a king, so God gave them Saul, son of Kish, from the tribe of Benjamin. After forty years
13.22: God removed Saul and made David their king. God spoke favorably about David. He said, ‘I have found that David, son of Jesse, is a man after my own heart. He will do everything I want him to do.’
13.23: “God had the Savior, Yeshua, come to Israel from David’s descendants, as he had promised.

‘I have made you a light for the nations
    so that you would save people all over the world.’”

14.1: The same thing happened in the city of Iconium. Paul and Barnabas went into the synagogue and spoke in such a way that a large crowd of Jews and Greeks believed.
14.2: But the Jews who refused to believe stirred up some people who were not Jewish and poisoned their minds against the believers.
14.3: Paul and Barnabas stayed in the city of Iconium for a long time. They spoke boldly about the Lord, who confirmed their message about his good will by having them perform miracles and do amazing things.
14.4: But the people of Iconium were divided. Some were for the Jews, while others were for the apostles.

14.6: So they escaped to Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and to the surrounding territory.
14.7: They spread the Good News there.
14.8: A man who was born lame was in Lystra. He was always sitting because he had never been able to walk.
14.9: He listened to what Paul was saying. Paul observed him closely and saw that the man believed he could be made well.
14.10: So Paul said in a loud voice, “Stand up.” The man jumped up and began to walk.
14.11: The crowds who saw what Paul had done shouted in the Lycaonian language, “The gods have come to us, and they look human.”
14.12: They addressed Barnabas as Zeus and Paul as Hermes because Paul did most of the talking.
14.13: Zeus’ temple was at the entrance to the city. The priest of the god Zeus brought bulls with flowery wreaths around their necks to the temple gates. The priest and the crowd wanted to offer a sacrifice to Paul and Barnabas.

14.15: and said, “Men, what are you doing? We’re human beings like you. We’re spreading the Good News to you to turn you away from these worthless gods to the living God. The living God made the sky, the land, the sea, and everything in them.

14.17: Yet, by doing good, he has given evidence of his existence. He gives you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons. He fills you with food and your lives with happiness.”
14.18: Although Paul and Barnabas said these things, they hardly kept the crowd from sacrificing to them.
14.19: However, Jews from the cities of Antioch and Iconium arrived in Lystra and won the people over. They tried to stone Paul to death and dragged him out of the city when they thought that he was dead.
14.20:
But when the disciples gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city.
The next day Paul and Barnabas left for the city of Derbe.
14.21: They spread the Good News in that city and won many disciples. Then they went back to the cities of Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch (which is in Pisidia).
14.22: They strengthened the disciples in these cities and encouraged the disciples to remain faithful. Paul and Barnabas told them, “We must suffer a lot to enter the kingdom of God.”
14.23: They had the disciples in each church choose spiritual leaders, and with prayer and fasting they entrusted the leaders to the Lord in whom they believed.
14.24: After they had gone through Pisidia, they went to Pamphylia.
14.25: They spoke the message in the city of Perga and went to the city of Attalia.
14.26: From Attalia they took a boat and headed home to the city of Antioch in Syria. (In Antioch they had been entrusted to God’s care for the work they had now finished.)
14.27: When they arrived, they called the members of the church together. They reported everything God had done through them, especially that he had given people who were not Jewish the opportunity to believe.
14.28: They stayed for a long time with these disciples.

15.1: Some men came from Judea and started to teach believers that people can’t be saved unless they are circumcised as Moses’ Teachings require.

15.3: The church sent Paul and Barnabas to Jerusalem. As they were going through Phoenicia and Samaria, they told the whole story of how non-Jewish people were turning to God. This story brought great joy to all the believers.
15.4: The church in Jerusalem, the apostles, and the spiritual leaders welcomed Paul and Barnabas when they arrived. Paul and Barnabas reported everything that God had done through them.
15.5: But some believers from the party of the Pharisees stood up and said, “People who are not Jewish must be circumcised and ordered to follow Moses’ Teachings.”
15.6: The apostles and spiritual leaders met to consider this statement.

15.8: God, who knows everyone’s thoughts, showed that he approved of people who aren’t Jewish by giving them the Holy Spirit as he gave the Holy Spirit to us.
15.9: God doesn’t discriminate between Jewish and non-Jewish people. He has cleansed non-Jewish people through faith as he has cleansed us Jews.
15.10: So why are you testing God? You’re putting a burden on the disciples, a burden neither our ancestors nor we can carry.
15.11: We certainly believe that the Lord Yeshua saves us the same way that he saves them—through his kindness.”
15.12: The whole crowd was silent. They listened to Barnabas and Paul tell about all the miracles and amazing things that God had done through them among non-Jewish people.
15.13: After they finished speaking, James responded, “Brothers, listen to me.

15.16:
‘Afterwards, I will return.

15.17:
so that the survivors and all the people who aren’t Jewish

        may search for the Lord, declares the Lord.

15.22: Then the apostles, the spiritual leaders, and the whole church decided to choose some of their men to send with Paul and Barnabas to the city of Antioch. They chose Judas (called Barsabbas) and Silas, who were leaders among the believers.
15.23:
They wrote this letter for them to deliver:
From the apostles and the spiritual leaders, your brothers.
To their non-Jewish brothers and sisters in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia.
Dear brothers and sisters,

15.29:
by keeping away from food sacrificed to false gods, from eating bloody meat, from eating the meat of strangled animals, and from sexual sins. If you avoid these things, you will be doing what’s right.
Farewell!
15.30: So the men were sent on their way and arrived in the city of Antioch. They gathered the congregation together and delivered the letter.

16.1: Paul arrived in the city of Derbe and then went to Lystra, where a disciple named Timothy lived. Timothy’s mother was a Jewish believer, but his father was Greek.
16.2: The believers in Lystra and Iconium spoke well of Timothy.
16.3: Paul wanted Timothy to go with him. So he circumcised him because of the Jews who lived in those places and because he knew that Timothy’s father was Greek.
16.4: As they went through the cities, they told people about the decisions that the apostles and spiritual leaders in Jerusalem had made for the people.
16.5: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew in numbers every day.
16.6: Paul and Silas went through the regions of Phrygia and Galatia because the Holy Spirit kept them from speaking the word in the province of Asia.
16.7: They went to the province of Mysia and tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Yeshua wouldn’t allow this.
16.8: So they passed by Mysia and went to the city of Troas.
16.9: During the night Paul had a vision of a man from Macedonia. The man urged Paul, “Come to Macedonia to help us.”
16.10: As soon as Paul had seen the vision, we immediately looked for a way to go to Macedonia. We concluded that God had called us to tell the people of Macedonia about the Good News.
16.11: So we took a ship from Troas and sailed straight to the island of Samothrace. The next day we sailed to the city of Neapolis,
16.12: and from there we went to the city of Philippi. Philippi is a leading city in that part of Macedonia, and it is a Roman colony. We were in this city for a number of days.
16.13: On the day of worship we went out of the city to a place along the river where we thought Jewish people gathered for prayer. We sat down and began talking to the women who had gathered there.
16.14: A woman named Lydia was present. She was a convert to Judaism from the city of Thyatira and sold purple dye for a living. She was listening because the Lord made her willing to pay attention to what Paul said.
16.15: When Lydia and her family were baptized, she invited us to stay at her home. She said, “If you’re convinced that I believe in the Lord, then stay at my home.” She insisted. So we did.
16.16: One day when we were going to the place of prayer, a female servant met us. She was possessed by an evil spirit that told fortunes. She made a lot of money for her owners by telling fortunes.
16.17: She used to follow Paul and shout, “These men are servants of the Most High God. They’re telling you how you can be saved.”
16.18:
She kept doing this for many days. Paul became annoyed, turned to the evil spirit, and said, “I command you in the name of Yeshua Christ to come out of her!”
As Paul said this, the evil spirit left her.
16.19: When her owners realized that their hope of making money was gone, they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them to the authorities in the public square.
16.20: In front of the Roman officials, they said, “These men are stirring up a lot of trouble in our city. They’re Jews,
16.21: and they’re advocating customs that we can’t accept or practice as Roman citizens.”
16.22: The crowd joined in the attack against Paul and Silas. Then the officials tore the clothes off Paul and Silas and ordered the guards to beat them with sticks.
16.23: After they had hit Paul and Silas many times, they threw them in jail and ordered the jailer to keep them under tight security.
16.24: So the jailer followed these orders and put Paul and Silas into solitary confinement with their feet in leg irons.
16.25: Around midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns of praise to God. The other prisoners were listening to them.
16.26: Suddenly, a violent earthquake shook the foundations of the jail. All the doors immediately flew open, and all the prisoners’ chains came loose.
16.27: The jailer woke up and saw the prison doors open. Thinking the prisoners had escaped, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself.
16.28: But Paul shouted as loudly as he could, “Don’t hurt yourself! We’re all here!”
16.29: The jailer asked for torches and rushed into the jail. He was trembling as he knelt in front of Paul and Silas.
16.30: Then he took Paul and Silas outside and asked, “Sirs, what do I have to do to be saved?”
16.31: They answered, “Believe in the Lord Yeshua, and you and your family will be saved.”
16.32: They spoke the Lord’s word to the jailer and everyone in his home.
16.33: At that hour of the night, the jailer washed Paul and Silas’ wounds. The jailer and his entire family were baptized immediately.
16.34: He took Paul and Silas upstairs into his home and gave them something to eat. He and his family were thrilled to be believers in God.
16.35: In the morning the Roman officials sent guards who told the jailer, “You can release those men now.”
16.36: The jailer reported this order to Paul by saying, “The officials have sent word to release you. So you can leave peacefully now.”
16.37: But Paul told the guards, “Roman officials have had us beaten publicly without a trial and have thrown us in jail, even though we’re Roman citizens. Now are they going to throw us out secretly? There’s no way they’re going to get away with that! Have them escort us out!”
16.38: The guards reported to the officials what Paul had said. When the Roman officials heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens, they were afraid.
16.39: So the officials went to the jail and apologized to Paul and Silas. As the officials escorted Paul and Silas out of the jail, they asked them to leave the city.
16.40: After Paul and Silas left the jail, they went to Lydia’s house. They met with the believers, encouraged them, and then left.

17.1: Paul and Silas traveled through the cities of Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to the city of Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue.
17.2: As usual, Paul went into the synagogue. On three consecutive days of worship, he had discussions about Scripture with the synagogue members.
17.3: He explained and showed them that the Messiah had to suffer, die, and come back to life, and that Yeshua, the person he talked about, was this Messiah.
17.4: Some of the Jews were persuaded to join Paul and Silas, especially a large group of Greeks who had converted to Judaism and the wives of many prominent men.
17.5: Then the Jews became jealous. They took some low-class characters who hung around the public square, formed a mob, and started a riot in the city. They attacked Jason’s home and searched it for Paul and Silas in order to bring them out to the crowd.
17.6: When they didn’t find Paul and Silas, they dragged Jason and some other believers in front of the city officials. They shouted, “Those men who have made trouble all over the world are now here in Thessalonica,
17.7: and Jason has welcomed them as his guests. All of them oppose the emperor’s decrees by saying that there is another king, whose name is Yeshua.”
17.8: The crowd and the officials were upset when they heard this.
17.9: But after they had made Jason and the others post bond, they let them go.
17.10:
Immediately when night came, the believers sent Paul and Silas to the city of Berea.
When Paul and Silas arrived in the city of Berea, they entered the synagogue.
17.11: The people of Berea were more open-minded than the people of Thessalonica. They were very willing to receive God’s message, and every day they carefully examined the Scriptures to see if what Paul said was true.
17.12: Many of them became believers, and quite a number of them were prominent Greek men and women.
17.13: But when the Jews in Thessalonica found out that Paul was also spreading God’s word in Berea, they went there to upset and confuse the people.
17.14: The believers immediately sent Paul to the seacoast, but Silas and Timothy stayed in Berea.
17.15: The men who escorted Paul took him all the way to the city of Athens. When the men left Athens, they took instructions back to Silas and Timothy to join Paul as soon as possible.
17.16: While Paul was waiting for Silas and Timothy in Athens, he saw that the city had statues of false gods everywhere. This upset him.
17.17: He held discussions in the synagogue with Jews and converts to Judaism. He also held discussions every day in the public square with anyone who happened to be there.
17.18: Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers had discussions with him. Some asked, “What is this babbling fool trying to say?” Others said, “He seems to be speaking about foreign gods.” The philosophers said these things because Paul was telling the Good News about Yeshua and saying that people would come back to life.
17.19: Then they brought Paul to the city court, the Areopagus, and asked, “Could you tell us these new ideas that you’re teaching?
17.20: Some of the things you say sound strange to us. So we would like to know what they mean.”
17.21: Everyone who lived in Athens looked for opportunities to tell or hear something new and unusual.
17.22: Paul stood in the middle of the court and said, “Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious.
17.23: As I was going through your city and looking closely at the objects you worship, I noticed an altar with this written on it: ‘To an unknown god.’ I’m telling you about the unknown god you worship.
17.24: The God who made the universe and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth. He doesn’t live in shrines made by humans,
17.25: and he isn’t served by humans as if he needed anything. He gives everyone life, breath, and everything they have.
17.26: From one man he has made every nation of humanity to live all over the earth. He has given them the seasons of the year and the boundaries within which to live.
17.27: He has done this so that they would look for God, somehow reach for him, and find him. In fact, he is never far from any one of us.
17.28: Certainly, we live, move, and exist because of him. As some of your poets have said, ‘We are God’s children.’
17.29: So if we are God’s children, we shouldn’t think that the divine being is like an image made from gold, silver, or stone, an image that is the product of human imagination and skill.
17.30: “God overlooked the times when people didn’t know any better. But now he commands everyone everywhere to turn to him and change the way they think and act.
17.31: He has set a day when he is going to judge the world with justice, and he will use a man he has appointed to do this. God has given proof to everyone that he will do this by bringing that man back to life.”
17.32: When the people of the court heard that a person had come back to life, some began joking about it, while others said, “We’ll hear you talk about this some other time.”
17.33: With this response, Paul left the court.
17.34: Some men joined him and became believers. With them were Dionysius, who was a member of the court, and a woman named Damaris, and some other people.

18.1: After this, Paul left Athens and went to the city of Corinth.
